citation.article-title: Helicobacter marmotae sp. nov. isolated from livers of woodchucks and intestines of cats.

p.s: Description of Helicobacter marmotae sp. nov.

Helicobacter marmotae (mar'mo.tae. F marmotte, fusion of OF marmotte, a monkey, and Romansch murmont, a marmot [L mus, muris, a mouse, plus montis, a mountain], relating to a short-tailed burrowing rodent species found in North America.)
Cells are slender, curved to spiral rods (0.2 by 1.5 to 5 μm), which have one to three spirals.
The bacterium is gram negative and nonsporulating; it is motile by means of sheathed, single unipolar or bipolar flagella.
Cultures grown on solid agar media appear as spreading layers.
Cells exhibit microaerobic but not aerobic or anaerobic growth.
The bacteria are oxidase, catalase, urease, and alkaline phosphatase positive but γ-glutamyl transpeptidase negative.
The organism does not hydrolyze indoxyl acetate nor reduce nitrate to nitrite.
Cells are resistant to nalidixic acid and cephalothin.
Bacteria have been isolated from the liver of woodchucks and feces of clinically normal cats.
The type strain is MIT 98-6070 (ATCC BAA-546).
The 16S rRNA sequence accession no. for the type strain is AF333341.
